intro: Centropogon subandinus, commonly known as the Andean torchflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its striking red or orange tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, often in rocky or alpine regions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and branched. Centropogon subandinus is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
